Warner Bros./DC will look to have a big 2017 and that starts with Gal Gadot as Wonder Woman. (Warner Bros.)

Troy L. Smith, cleveland.com

Summer Movie Preview

CLEVELAND, Ohio – For the past several years, summer movie season has been all about superhero movies, adaptations and sequels challenging each other at the box office.

2017 is all that much different with titles like “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2,” “Wonder Woman,” “Baywatch” and “Despicable Me 3” leading the way. But this summer will offer up some fresh material.

Christopher Nolan is delivering his first war epic with “Dunkirk.” Guy Ritchie taking the classic King Arthur story. And a new biopic will tell the story of one of hip-hop’s greatest icons.

Don't Edit

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 (May 5)

Summer movie season begins here, with the follow-up to Marvel’s surprise blockbuster “Guardians of the Galaxy.” This time around we get the big reveal of Star-Lord’s father (Kurt Russell), as the team of heroes (including Baby Groot) try to save the world again with the help of a few frenemies.

Don't Edit

King Arthur: Legend of the Sword (May 12)

Director Guy Ritchie teams up with Charlie Hunnam (“Sons of Anarchy”) for a stylish take on a classic story that turns to chaos once Arthur pulls that sword from that stone.

Don't Edit

Snatched (May 12)

Amy Schumer plays a mess of a woman (shocker) who goes on vacation with her equally messed up mom (Goldie Hawn) for an adventure in a tropical paradise.

Don't Edit

Alien: Covenant (May 19)

Ridley Scott will look to make up for the puzzling 2012 film “Prometheus” with yet another “Alien” prequel aimed to explain the franchise’s origins. When will people in movies learn to stop going to outer space?

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Baywatch (May 26)

Dwayne Johnson and Zac Efron lead a cast of beautiful people in a film adaptation of one of the most popular TV series of all time. “Baywatch” wisely takes the raunchy comedy route that both Johnson and Efron have fared well at.

Don't Edit

Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (May 26)

Should the “Pirates of the Caribbean” franchise be over already? I guess we’ll find out when Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) takes on a group of ghost sailors, led by Javier Bardem, in the latest installment.

Don't Edit

War Machine (May 26)

Netflix enters the summer movie game with “War Machine.” Brad Pitt plays a four-star general during the war in Afghanistan, only to find himself in the news for all the wrong reasons.

Don't Edit

Wonder Woman (June 2)

Warner Bros./DC will look to get back in moviegoers’ good graces this year and “Wonder Woman” may be the perfect movie to kick things off. The throwback story looks to tell the origins of the greatest female comic-book hero with a vibe similar to that of Marvel’s “Captain America: The First Avenger.”

Don't Edit

The Mummy (June 9)

This isn’t the fun adventure story the previous “Mummy” franchise was made to be. Tom Cruise stars in the edgy reboot that turns up the terror thanks to an ancient queen.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Cars 3 (June 16)

“Cars” sometimes gets a bad rap as Pixar’s weakest franchise (and maybe rightfully so). But the third installment could change that, as Lightning McQueen finds himself as the veteran racecar looking to hold on to his top spot.

Don't Edit

Rough Night (June 16)

An all-star cast of actresses – Scarlett Johansson, Zoe Kravitz, Kate McKinnon, Jillian Bell and Ilana Glazer – lead “Rough Night,” the story of a bachelorette party gone bad after the women accidentally kill a male stripper.

Don't Edit

The Book of Henry (June 16)

Young actor Jacob Tremblay follows up his standout turn in “The Room” with “The Book of Henry.” Tremblay plays one of two brothers in a suburban town, raised by their single mother (Naomi Watts).

Don't Edit

All Eyez on Me (June 16)

Fresh off the induction of Tupac Shakur into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, fans will get a mainstream movie documenting the late rapper’s life and death. “All Eyez on Me” looks to carry the same vibe as other hip-hop biopics like “Straight Outta Compton” and “Notorious.”

Don't Edit

Transformers: The Last Knight (June 23)

Optimus Prime as a bad guy? That looks to be the case in the fifth “Transformers” film. Michael Bay brings together parts of the casts from his two versions of the franchise, with Mark Wahlberg, Stanley Tucci and others joining Josh Duhamel and Tyrese Gibson.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Okja (June 28)

The hype surrounding Bong Joon-ho’s new Netflix movie has a lot do with how great his pervious feature, “Snowpiercer,” was. “Okja” centers on a young girl who goes to great lengths to keep a corporation from kidnapping her BFF, which happens to be a massive creature.

Don't Edit

Baby Driver (June 28)

Edgar Wright’s “Baby Driver” is one of the most intriguing films of 2017. It certainly has the cast – Jamie Foxx, Ansel Elgort, Kevin Spacey, Jon Hamm and more – to back it up. The movie centers on Baby (Elgort) a getaway driver who meets his dream girl and wants to start a new life.

Don't Edit

Despicable Me 3 (June 30)

The “Despicable Me” franchise looks to continue its lucrative winning streak, as Gru takes on a former child star turned adversary as well as his twin brother Dru.

Don't Edit

The House (June 30)

Two of comedy’s most reliable players join forces when Amy Pohler and Will Ferrell play a couple who starts an underground casino to pay for their daughter’s college tuition.

Don't Edit

Spider-Man: Homecoming (July 7)

All signs point to Tom Holland as the right choice to revive the Spider-Man film franchise. This time around, high school student Peter Parker must come to terms with his powers with help from Iron Man as they battle Vulture (Michael Keaton).

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

War of the Planet of the Apes (July 14)

The latest version of the “Planet of the Apes” franchise has quietly featured some of the most satisfying action films in recent memory. “War of the Planet of the Apes” will move things even further as Caesar leads his apes against an army of humans.

Don't Edit

Dunkirk (July 21)

Christopher Nolan’s war epic promises to be one of the biggest moves of the year. The acclaimed director tells the story of Allied troops stranded on a beach in France during World War II and the heroics required to barely stay alive.

Don't Edit

Valerian and the City of Thousand Planets (July 21)

Based on the popular comic book series "Valerian and Laureline," the Luc Besson directed film is set in the 28th century and focused on two operatives looking to keep the peace in a world that visually should blow you mind.

Don't Edit

Atomic Blonde (July 28)

Charlize Theron goes into full action mode as a member of Her Majesty’s Secret Intelligence Service with all the skills necessary to (hopefully) survive the most dangerous mission of her career.

Don't Edit

The Emoji Movie (July 28)

If they can make a movie out of Angry Birds, why not emojis? “The Emoji Movie” dives into the fictional world of the playful faces you use to punctuate your text messages.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power (July 28)

With President Donald Trump willing to cut funding for green initiatives, a sequel to Al Gore’s landmark documentary seems appropriate at this time. Gore continues travelling the world to educate people about climate change.

Don't Edit

The Dark Tower (Aug. 4)

Fingers crossed “The Dark Tower” finally comes out. The film based on the Stephen King novels of the same name has been delayed several times. Still, fans are eagerly anticipating the project, which stars Idris Elba and Matthew McConaughey.

Don't Edit

Annabelle: Creation (Aug. 11)

These days, if you deliver one good horror film, you take it and run with it. That’s been the case with the successful “The Conjuring” franchise, which has featured the story of the creepy doll Annabelle. We’ll get her origin story this summer.

Don't Edit
